review_title: Good learning opportunity for those new to the IT field
pros: Great benefits, excellent time off, almost all of the faculty and staff are a pleasure to work with, able to take ownership of your own projects if you prove you are competent, get to work with enterprise level technology with a small staff, which means you can learn a lot quickly
cons: Salary could be better, small staff size means that it's nearly impossible to move up in your position unless someone else leaves.  Office politics can slow down or kill some of the better ideas.  Incompetent people tend to stay in their position for too long due to the conservative nature of the senior management.  Don't always get to use or learn the latest technology or practices due to budget constraints or ingrained conservative attitude.

pros:
I am a student here at Georgia Military College and part of the Student Ambassador Program.

They have flexible hours. Because you have to be a student to get this job they are very understanding if you need to take off some time to study for classes or anything. You sign up for hours yourself, and you can change those hours as long as you give them advanced notice.

It's an easy job. Most of the work you would do is simple enough that you can get all your homework done while getting paid.

The pay is good. Given that this job is incredibly easy, paying more than minimum wage impresses me.
cons: Sometimes, if you have no homework, you can end up sitting still for hours with nothing happening. But, this might be a Pro for some people!

review_title: Be willing to do any and everything for recognition
job_title: Non Exempt Staff in Augusta, GA
pros: vacation and sick time earned monthly. Time off during most holidays.
cons: Morale is low because pay is much lower than industry standards. Must be willing to do "odd jobs" to be considered a team player i.e. cleaning walls, moving furniture. You are expected to volunteer during off time. Management doesn't understand the rules of overtime and gets offended when questioned about it.

review_title: I would read this before you apply...
pros:
(Not a motorman, no way I’m putting what I do because they are petty enough to try to figure it out)
You get a decent amount of time off and state benefits are good (except for mandatory TRS- which is a rip-off compared to other retirement plans - the program is also a constant target for budget cuts in the state senate.)
cons:
Oh boy, where do I start. I’ll do a “big three” format.

1. Administration/executives  don’t value or respect employees - administration is not transparent - would rather rapidly onboard new employees and let them become gradually dissatisfied and quit than make a concerted effort to improve workplace morale.

- So the root of the issue here is that GMC is a deadbeat dad of employers. The school seems to have an endless supply of money and fundraising energy for flashy new things that it thinks will win it brownie points with big donors and Milledgeville, but simultaneously grumbles on about the employees wanting pay that isn’t way below industry standards (I could make double what I make not working in rural Georgia where they use the relative poverty and and low cost of living to screw you out of potential earnings). It’s all stick and no carrot, and if you even ask about a carrot, you’re going to be seen as a rebellious employee by HR. Your reward for a job well done is not getting chewed out. You’ll gradually become infuriated with the feel-good, bootstrap corporate propaganda they put out internally which thinly masks the fact that they would rather an employee quit than have to entertain the idea of paying them what the market deems to be a fair price for their talent.

2. Executive incompetence

GMC’s Lack of drive to modernize and normalize its workplace to 2020 standards is primarily the fault of its executives. Antiquated boomers and wacky generals waiting to retire and get their max pension benefits - the executive administration has no vision, no heart, and no will to find either. This lack of leadership trickles down and is palpable in the absolute lack of professionalism some employees show to one another. You will encounter people making 2-3x your salary who don’t know how to use essential Microsoft office software applications and wonder how they’ve managed to work for so long not knowing how Microsoft office functions , only to realize you answered your own question. 

3. Fear-based work culture

We have office bullies. My office actually has multiple office bullies at the moment. Be prepared to be manipulated and made to feel anxious. 

HR will snitch on you for coming to them for help. They will immediately call your director and tell them everything you said in confidence. HR is there to protect the school and the executives. They will not protect you from your toxic work environment because they are the ones enabling it.

Execs and directors don’t trust employees to do their jobs, I’m guessing because those paranoid about something generally engage in the very act they are paranoid about. Seems to be a lot of chiefs and not enough Indians. 

But hey - you’ll rise quickly as your peers gradually move to greener pastures.
